SubTopics: Solve problems involving operations (+, -, ×, and ÷) with whole numbers, decimals (through thousandths), straight computation, or word problems.

Key.Rationale: Multiplies the 2 by only the whole-number part of 2.036 to get 4.036.
Multiplies the 2 by 2.036 to get 4.072 and then subtracts 2.268.
Subtracts high digit minus low digit in 4.072 - 2.268.
Multiplies the 2 by only the whole-number part of 2.036 to get 4.036, and subtracts high digit minus low digit in 4.036 - 2.268.

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving division of fractions.
Content: Grace has 15 3/4 cups of plant food.

:box:• She divides the plant food equally into 3 bags.

• She uses all the plant food in 1 of the bags to feed her potted flowers.

• She feeds each potted flower 3/4 cup of plant food.
How many potted flowers does Grace feed?

Key.Rationale: Divides 15 3/4 by 3 to get 5 1/4, and then subtracts 3/4 from 5 1/4.
Subtracts 3/4 from 15 3/4 to get 15, and then divides 15 by 3.
Divides 15 3/4 by 3 to get 5 1/4, retains the whole number (5), and then subtracts 1/4 from 3/4.
Divides 15 3/4 by 3 to get 5 1/4, and then divides 5 1/4 by 3/4.

SubTopics: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1-100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
Solve problems involving operations (+, -, ×, and ÷) with whole numbers, decimals (through thousandths), straight computation, or word problems.
Content: Ivan packed 56 apples and 72 pears into boxes. He packed both apples and pears into each box. He put the same number of apples into every box and the same number of pears into every box. He sold each box for $19.95. What is the greatest amount of money Ivan could earn selling all the boxes of fruit?

Key.Rationale: Uses 2 as the GCF and multiplies $19.95 by 2.
Uses 4 as the GCF and multiplies $19.95 by 4.
Determines the common factors of 56 and 72 (1, 2, 4, 8), identifies 8 as the GCF, and multiplies 8 by $19.95.
Factors 56 as 9 × 6, uses 9 as the GCF, and multiplies $19.95 by 9.

SubTopics: Determine the opposite of a number and recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself (e.g., -(-3) = 3; 0 is its own opposite).
Content: Which statement about the opposite of a number is correct?

Key.Rationale: Knows 5 • 1/5 = 1, so thinks 1/5 is the opposite (i.e., confuses with the multiplicative inverse).
Recognizes 0 as its own opposite since 0(-1) = 0.
Knows -5(0) = 0, so thinks 0 is the opposite (i.e., confuses with the multiplicative property of 0).
Knows -5(1) = -5, so thinks 1 is the opposite (i.e., confuses with the identity property of multiplication).

SubTopics: Interpret the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line and as a magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation.
Content: Which number line shows a point graphed at every location that represents a number with an absolute value of 4.5?

Key.Rationale: Omits -4.5.
Omits 4.5 (may think absolute value is equivalent to “the opposite of”).
Identifies the two points that are each 4.5 units away from 0 — one negative (to the left) and one positive (to the right).
Uses -4.5, but includes an additional 4.5 in the negative direction.

SubTopics: Construct tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole-number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and/or plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.
Find the unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b (with b ≠ 0) and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship.
Content: Elliot plants lettuce and onions in his garden. He always plants the same ratio of lettuce plants to onion plants, as shown in the table below.
problems/PA21G6M/media/6a.jpg
Based on the information in the table, how many onion plants would Elliot plant for 1 lettuce plant?

Key.Rationale: Identifies the ratio of lettuce plants to onion plants as 1:3 and applies this ratio by multiplying the number of lettuce plants (1) by 3 to determine the number of onion plants.
Identifies the ratio of lettuce plants to onion plants as 1:3 but misapplies the ratio by adding 3 to the number of lettuce plants (1).
Starting from the bottom, uses “subtract 6” as the pattern in the onion column.
Using the first two rows, solves 4 - [_] = 1 to set up 12 - 3.

SubTopics: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
Content: Which expression has the least value?

Key.Rationale: Selects the expression with the lowest-value exponent.
Selects the expression with a single term.
Applies the exponents to determine the value of each expression (4 + 12 = 16, 4 • 4 • 4 = 64, 25 - 4 • 4 = 9, 4 • 4 • 4 • 4 - 160 = 96) and selects the expression with the least value.
Selects the expression that shows the subtraction of the greatest number.

SubTopics: Write algebraic expressions from verbal descriptions.
Identify parts of an expression using mathematical terms (e.g., sum, term, product, factor, quotient, coefficient, quantity).

Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving whole-number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order (Order of Operations).
Content: An algebraic expression is described below.
six more than the product of four times the difference between x and 3
What is the value of the expression when x = 8?

Key.Rationale: Writes the expression as 6 + x(4 - 3), switching the x and the 4, and then substitutes 8 in for x to get 6 + 8 • (4 - 3) = 6 + 8 • 1 = 6 + 8 = 14.
Writes the expression as 6 + 4(x - 3) and then substitutes 8 in for x to get 6 + 4 (8 - 3) = 6 + 4 • 5 = 6 + 20 = 26.
Writes the expression as 6 + 4x - 3, omitting the grouping symbols, and then substitutes 8 in for x to get 6 + 4 • 8 - 3 = 6 + 32 - 3 = 38 - 3 = 35.
Writes the expression as 6 + 4(x - 3), substitutes 8 in for x, subtracts 3 from 8 first to get 6 + 4 • 5, but then adds 6 and 4 before multiplying by 5.

SubTopics: Interpret and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
Content: Marty read x books. Jackie read 28 books, which is 6 books more than the number of books Marty read. The equation below can be used to find the number of books Marty read.
Ron read 3 times as many books as Marty. How many books did Ron read?

Key.Rationale: Subtracts 6 from both sides of the equation to get x = 22, which is the number of books Marty read.
Attempts to solve for x by adding 6 to 28 to get x = 34 and then does not multiply by 3.
Subtracts 6 from both sides of the equation to get x = 22 and then multiplies 22 by 3.
Writes Ron's expression as 3 × 28 - 6 (i.e., omits grouping symbols).

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: A gray whale swims 161 kilometers in 24 hours. The equation below can be used to find the rate (r), in kilometers per hour (kph), at which the gray whale swims.
Rounded to the nearest tenth, what is the rate at which the gray whale swims?

Key.Rationale: Multiplies 161 by 24 and moves the decimal.
Multiplies 161 by 24, moves the decimal, and rounds up.
Divides 161 by 24 to get 6.708333... and rounds down.
Correctly divides 161 by 24 but rounds up.

SubTopics: Write an equation to express the relationship between the dependent and independent variables.
Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables and/or relate these to an equation.
Content: The table below shows the relationship between the number of tables and the number of chairs in each of three meeting rooms of an office building.
problems/PA21G6M/media/11a.jpg
Which equation describes the relationship between the number of tables and the number of chairs in each meeting room?

Key.Rationale: Uses 3 from the first table pair.
Determines that the number of chairs is always 8 times the number of tables.
Uses 24 - 3 from the first table pair.
Uses 24 from the first table pair.

SubTopics: Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables and/or relate these to an equation.
Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: A store is having a sale. All items are discounted 20% off the original price. Which table shows the relationship between the original price and the discount?

Key.Rationale: Equates 20% with 0.20 and uses a pattern of “add $0.20” in the Discount column.
Uses 20% = 0.20 and multiplies each value in the Original Price column by 0.20.
Multiplies by 0.02.
Moves the decimal to the left 1 place, subtracts 0.20, and rounds down to the nearest nickel (if necessary).

SubTopics: Determine the area of irregular or compound polygons.
Content: A figure is shown below.
problems/PA21G6M/media/13a.jpg
What is the area of the figure?

Key.Rationale: Separates the figure into a 15-by-12 rectangle and a 5-by-5 square, determines the partial areas to be 15 • 12 = 180 and 5 • 5 = 25, and then adds the partial areas OR separates the figure into a 12-by-10 rectangle and a 17-by-5 rectangle, determines the partial areas to be 12 • 10 = 120 and 17 • 5 = 85, and then adds the partial areas OR determines the area of the “greater” rectangle to be 15 • 17 = 255 and then subtracts the area of the upper-right 10-by-5 rectangle.
Determines the area of the 17-by-15 rectangle and subtracts 5 × 5 (instead of subtracting 5 × 10).
Divides the figure into two rectangles with a horizontal line, but adds 17 × 5 and 15 × 12 (instead of adding 10 × 12).
Determines the area of the 17-by-15 rectangle and adds 5 × 5 (instead of subtracting 5 × 10).

SubTopics: Determine the volume of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths.
Content: A rectangular prism is pictured below.
problems/PA21G6M/media/14a.jpg
What is the volume of the rectangular prism?

Key.Rationale: Adds edge lengths and then multiplies the sum by 3.
Multiplies edge lengths and then divides the product by 3.
Adds the product of whole numbers to the product of fractions.
Uses the volume formula for a rectangular prism (V = lwh) to multiply 16 1/2 by 4 by 9 1/4.

SubTopics: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made of rectangles and triangles.
Content: A three-dimensional figure is pictured below.
problems/PA21G6M/media/15a.jpg
Which net could form the three-dimensional figure when folded along the dashed line segments?

Key.Rationale: Selects a net with all triangular faces.
Selects a net with a rectangular base, but the lateral faces are not triangular.
Selects a net with rectangular and triangular faces but reverses the locations of rectangles and triangles.
Identifies that the base is a rectangle and each lateral face is a triangle and selects a net composed of a rectangle surrounded by four triangles.

SubTopics: Determine quantitative measures of center (e.g., median, mean, mode) and variability (e.g., range, interquartile range, mean absolute deviation).
Content: A band has an album with 9 songs on it. The lengths of the songs, in seconds, are listed below.
What is the median song length, in seconds, of the 9 songs on the band's album?

Key.Rationale: Orders the list from least to greatest and identifies the middle value.
Determines the mean of the data.
Identifies the middle value in the unordered list.
Determines the mode of the data.

SubTopics: Display, analyze, and summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.
Content: Carlos surveyed 40 men about their shoe sizes. Carlos made the box-and-whisker plot below to display his results.
problems/PA21G6M/media/17a.jpg
What was the median shoe size of the 40 men Carlos surveyed? Explain how you found your answer.
Martin thinks more men have shoe sizes between 6 and 9 than between 11 1/2 and 13 because the whisker from 6 to 9 is longer than the whisker from 11 1/2 to 13.
Explain why Martin is NOT correct. As part of your explanation, find the number of men with shoe sizes in each interval and describe how you found those numbers.
